utterances: Not that we've heard of very much.
I think that most of the cities are trying to, you know, kind of things like pamphlets and educational programs, but there is nothing mandatory.
You now, its always seemed a little - kind of interesting to me that, you know, that people could kind of bike carefree but, you know, that there's quite a few restrictions in terms of driving.

And so, I think, you know, as we go more and more, there is going to be a bigger emphasis on education and so that people kind of understand how to do, you know, get over these kind of initial growing pains of more riders and how they coexist with drivers.
All right.
Let's go to Evie, she's calling from Denmark.
Hi, Evie.
Hi.
Yeah.
Thanks for taking my call.
I just want to say that it really can work, but I think the most important thing, more important than the right kind of bike lanes or anything, is education.
Because here in Denmark, riding bikes is just part of the culture, everybody rides bikes.
They are encouraged from kindergarten, and parents are encouraged to get their kids to ride to school and - so it's really a big part of the society.
One - another really nice thing, I mean, you are talking a lot about bike lanes and social streets and everything like that.
The great - a great thing that they have here is whole towns are connected by bike paths that are away from the streets.
So parents never have to worry about their kids being in traffic.
So I just was wondering if you knew anything about the way it's set up here, and if you could compare it.
That's an interesting question, Daisuke.

Did you know if cities across this country are studying or looking at what Europe has done because, you know, I know the first time I really saw really good bike lanes was in Germany many years ago, and I remember thinking, well that's a great idea.

Because even then I thought there were, you know, problems between drivers and this was like 20 years ago, and I thought that might help take care of some of these problems, if you had really well-marked lanes.
Yeah, I think Europe is the model in terms of how to find that balance, how to strike that balance between bikes and cars.
You know, Denmark is a great example.
There is also Amsterdam, which is, you know, another great bicycle city.
You know, I think that most cities are studying the best way to do this, and it's not easy, you know.
Obviously, there's proponents on either side.
And I found kind of an interesting one in New York recently when I was there on a trip and walking through this Chelsea neighborhood.
I saw that they have kind of bicycles - their own lanes now - in terms of not just bike lanes but a curve in between the sidewalk and the road, and then the bicycles come through there.
And then these bicycles also have their own traffic lights as well.
So I think more and more cities are putting forth the infrastructure to make this happen.
I mean, I think the west - the northwest has been a little bit ahead of the curve, especially a city like Portland.

And Boulder has been really ahead of the curve, in terms of setting up a lot of infrastructure so that it makes it easy for bikers to commute to work or even, you know, drop their kids off for a play date or whatever the case may be.
There's been a lot of work done there.
All right.
Thanks so much for calling in, Evie.
Thank you.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
(Singing) (Unintelligible)
And I just want to remind our audience that you are listening to Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
And Daisuke, I was just wondering, in cities like Portland, Oregon I think you mentioned that things - there are lot of bikers there - things seemed to be working out there.
What are they doing right?
Well, Portland is, I guess, widely considered America's most bike-friendly city.
I think that their kind of bike push started a long time ago - you know, maybe even well over a decade ago in terms of putting in bicycle lanes.
I think it started - it starts basically with kind of the citizens of that - the residents of that city, you know, being kind of outdoorsy and enjoying the physical activity of riding bicycles.
And so, once that kind of base has been set, you know, they do a good job of kind of establishing bicycle lanes.
Then they do a good job of kind of linking not only trains and buses so that trains and buses will carry bicycles.
They put forth things like a program where in downtown Portland, you can go and walk into a health club that you are not necessarily a member of and take a shower for a small fee.
You know, there's all sort of great things that Portland has done over the years to kind of encourage, you know, bicycle ridership.
And I think, you know, it's not a one- to two-year process; it's a decade-long process.
Well, we've got a caller from Portland, Oregon, on the line, Andrea.
Hi, Andrea.
Hi.
Thank you for taking my call.
I want to say, yeah.

I do agree, Portland has done some amazing things, but there's been kind of, like the first generation of bicycling activists really wanted to get the bike lanes on all the major streets and wanted to share the streets with the cars.
And I think the new thing that the city is really been pushing in the last several years has been bike boulevards, getting bikes completely off of the main streets.
And just giving, you know, really nice access to various parts of town without having to be on the big streets, because that makes people who aren't confident bike riders really nervous.
I mean, I've been riding my bike - I rode it in Chicago for years.

I was totally part of Critical Mass, and I still get really nervous having to, you know, stop in the middle of the road and make a left-hand turn properly, and hoping that the person behind me will actually see me, you know?
And it's - but I will say that even in Portland, where things are really bike friendly, things aren't perfect.

And I think that - my biking friends will, you know, not agree with me at all - but I do think that some sort license would be completely appropriate because it's - you know, I see people doing really, really, really dumb things on bikes.

And, I mean, obviously, I see bad drivers constantly, but this being the first time I've actually had to own a car, I become so wary when I have to, you know, deal with a bicyclist because I know that they're not going to necessarily act like I would expect another driver to act.

You know, and you - just yesterday, I saw some kid, you know, completely take a left turn in front of a car that was coming at 35 mph and not - and he just expected the car would slow down for him, and I'm just like, this is- it needs to be something that, you know, if you are going to share the road with the cars, you have to be expected to be responsible for yourself also.
All right.
Thanks so much for your call, Andrea.

So it seems like what we are hearing over and over again, Daisuke, is that maybe a little politeness on the part of both drivers and bicyclists is in order, as well as maybe some training and education.
So that might help, but thanks so much for joining us today, Daisuke.
Thank you.
Daisuke Wakabayashi is a correspondent with Reuters in Seattle, Washington.
And coming up, as we wait on Hillary Clinton's speech, we'll be talking with Gail Sheehy about where Hillary's at now.
I'm Lynn Neary, it's Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
Singer R.
Kelly has topped the charts since the early '90s.
His complicated lyrics veer from occasional gospel to the sexually explicit.
He's one of R&B's most successful and most notorious artists.
In 2002, a sex tape allegedly containing footage of R.
Kelly with a 13-year-old girl surfaced.
Now Kelly faces 14 counts of child pornography stemming from that tape.
Yesterday, the opening arguments against Robert Kelly began in a Chicago courtroom.
Reporter Steven Gray was there covering the trial for Time Magazine.
We'll speak with him in a moment.
If you have questions about the R.
Kelly trial, 800-989-8255, or send us an email at talk@npr.org.
Steven Gray is with is from the studios of WGN in Chicago and it's nice having you on Talk of the Nation today.
Nice to be here, Neal.
How are you?
And this trial only came about after six years of - a lot of people thought it would never happen.
That's right, Neal.
The charges came at about June of 2002, initially 21 counts of child pornography.
Eventually, seven of those charges were dropped.
And the trial - the case has essentially dragged on for seemingly bizarre reasons.
One reason was that Judge Gaughan, the presiding judge, he fell off a ladder and broke several bones.
Another time one of the lead prosecutors had a baby.
Just last December, R.
Kelly failed to make a scheduled court appearance because his speeding tour bus was stopped by authorities out in Utah, and so he couldn't make it out to back here to Chicago for court the next day.
So a lot of people were very skeptical about whether R.
Kelly would even face, you know, some jurors.
And the other thing that people were curious about, the tape in question - would it be played in court?
Obviously, his attorneys objected.
Yeah.
It was played on Tuesday, the first day of the actual trial.
It was 27 minutes long, roughly.
And - there's a wonderful description in your story about that, about how the jurors and the people in the courtroom and R.
Kelly himself, the defendant, reacted as the tape was played.
It was an extremely surreal event.

You know, it was - a couple of people said to me that it's the sort of thing they may have watched in the privacy of their own homes, and so it just felt very odd for many folks to sit there in a room full of dozens of other people watching that sort of thing.
Jurors were - there were mixed feelings among - mixed emotions from some of the jurors.
I remember seeing one guy put an ear - one juror put an arm or the hand over his ear.
One woman, a middle-aged black woman, a juror, she a couple times, in fact, she put her face down which - it seemed in disgust.
R.
Kelly at a couple points rocked back in his chair, and it seemed as if he couldn't even watch it at a couple points.
But it was definitely a surreal, odd experience.
The defense contends that's not him.
Tumblr is a New York-based social media and blogging site that's been growing rapidly, thanks in part to the exploding use of smartphones and tablets.
And then there's Yahoo, which desperately needs relevance, says Kara Swisher, co-editor of All Things D, which first reported the acquisition.
This is a site that's very hip and very cool, and has a much younger demographic than Yahoo does.
And so it's an attempt to try to marry the two together and hopefully, it will work out.
Some people think it will; some people think it won't.
It could be risky, at a reported $1.1 billion.
But Swisher says Yahoo doesn't have a lot of other options.
They tried to buy Facebook and were unsuccessful and so I think now, they just can't afford to make the mistakes on these up-and-coming sites that might help them continue to grow.
The reported deal is the biggest move yet in Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer's short tenure.
Mayer, who used to be an executive at Google, has been tasked with reinventing Yahoo; a charge that's already had some early successes, if the company's climbing stock prices are any indication.
Kirk Siegler, NPR News.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
NPR's business news starts with some tough luck in Atlantic City.
The Revel Casino in Atlantic City is not even a year old yet, but last night it filed for bankruptcy.
The move will turn over control to lenders.
The hope is that the casino can get rid of more than a billion dollars in debt.
But it is not lights out for the glitzy Revel.
The casino along with its hotel, theaters, restaurants and night clubs will remain open through the financial restructuring.
Revel hopes to emerge from bankruptcy by early summer but not be profitable for several more years.
There are people in New Jersey and New York who are beginning to get back to work.
And they're facing another problem: how to get gas for their vehicles to make that commute.

Because of widespread power outages, most of the gas stations in the region fall into one of two categories: They have power, but no gasoline, or they have gasoline, but no power to pump it into cars.
As NPR's Greg Allen reports, that leaves a small number of gas stations with very, very long lines.
Like thousands of motorists in New York and New Jersey, Eddie Pruchnick spent much of his day looking for gas.
He started at 6AM.
Three hours later, he was still waiting, a long line in Brooklyn.
I was up in the Bronx.
I couldn't find any gas in the Bronx, couldn't find any in Yonkers.
And I just took a chance.
I got on this line.
From Long Island to Central Jersey, a wave of panic has gripped motorists who want to get back to work, but need gas to do so.
An estimated three-quarters of the gas stations in North Jersey were shut down again yesterday, many because they don't have the electricity needed to power their pumps.
Others with gas have found an intense demand that often requires police intervention.
Police stepped in to stop fights and impose order at gas stations throughout New York and New Jersey.
At a station with gas in Brooklyn yesterday, motorist Jessica Laura described the scene there.
It was chaos.
People were fighting over here.
People were fighting over there.
People were coming through the wrong way.
It was chaos.
Then the cops came, and they just started organizing it.
As gas station needles drop toward E, gas hunters have turned to Twitter, posting news of what stations are open where.
But that news has a short shelf life.
I rushed to an Exxon station said to have gas only to discover they'd run out two hours earlier.
Owner Walid Nabath said he was expecting more gas at any moment.
Now I'm trying to call them to know what time we're going to get the gas delivery.
Would you expect a delivery today?
I wish.
I hope so.
(SOUNDBITE OF PHONE RINGING)
But we don't know.
You know, the phone can't stop.
